[i]Space Pilgrim Episode I: Alpha Centauri[/i] es el primer capítulo de la saga de ciencia ficción Space Pilgrim. Se trata de un buen juego de aventuras creado con RPG Maker, con todo lo que ello implica, es decir: jugabilidad muy simple y gráficos pixelados. 

A pesar de que dura poco (una hora y media o dos), me ha parecido que la narrativa es interesante, con atractivos giros de guión y ciertos toques de humor, y además creo que es una acertada manera de introducir a los personajes que, presumiblemente, serán los protagonistas de los siguientes episodios (digo presumiblemente porque aún no jugué los capítulos que siguen a este).

En resumen, si no te echan para atrás las limitaciones (jugables y audiovisuales) ya mencionadas, es una aventura interesante, y además es gratis.

77007765.review:
Since I'm currently re-watching ST:TNG and watching Lower Decks (which got better), I'm in a sci-fi mood.  And so I found this game.  This is an graphic adventure game.  That is, it is like the scavenger-hunt portion of a HOG, but without any mini-games or puzzles.  You can finish the entire game in a single play-through of a few hours.  

It is better at plot and story than most adventure games, because... well... for an adventure game, there really is hardly any scavenger-hunting.  You never have more than a few items in your inventory at any time, and you can't pick up (or sometimes even notice) items that you don't yet need.  So in this sense, the game is very, very linear.  You can't do anything to sabotage your game state, but you can't always advance until you do things in a particular order.  So the game is tightly on rails, ensuring that the plot is given to you always in the correct order.  This does make for a surprisingly strong story.  

Whether it makes for a surprisingly weak game is up to each person to decide.  However, the game was recently put on sale, and is now free to play.  It is part of a series of similar games, some taking place on a spaceship, some taking place on a deep space mining station, and I assume future installments are taking place in the Delta Quadrant, some taking place in a French vineyard, and so on.   (This episode ends with the female 2nd-in-command having to put on a red angel battle-mech armor that looks like it was created by Section 31, so my assumptions are probably spot-on.)  

The game was made with RPG Maker, so it's the usual Commodore 64 graphics.  No voices or voice-overs.  
There are no bugs and glitches, and all achievements are possible.

74835380.review:
RPG Maker strikes again! This is one of hundreds of low effort retro-pixel JRPG ripoffs spamming the Steam catalog, made with the RPG Maker video game construction kit... in their own words, "Our easy to use tools are simple enough for a child."  Like all RPG Maker "games", this is essentially a bunch of low quality/canned assets from RPG Maker coupled with a cringeworthy high school anime club weeaboo fan fiction. 

This particular RPG Maker game is slightly different than most in that the lazy fantasy theme has been replaced with a lazy sci-fi theme.  Some of the art assets seem to have been partially hand made, but are of worse quality than the RPG Maker assets that usually get flipped.   Typical for every RPG Maker game, the game has fixed resolution and doesn't display properly in fullscreen, in this case you get 4:3 aspect ratio, stretched. 

It is worth noting the developers give this game away free, which is a nice move, but gamers who want a good retro JRPG experience would be better off playing the originals, like Final Fantasy, Star Ocean or Chrono Trigger.

65467297.review:
The Space Pilgrim saga is basically 1 game divided into 4 separated episodes that, while they can be played individually, I really recommend going through all 4 of them in order, because that’s the proper way to play this. So, this is the same review for all 4 episodes as well.
That being said, while Space Pilgrim is obviously made using the RPG Maker engine, it’s not an RPG at all. This is an exploration adventure game, with item collecting and puzzle solving like point and click titles. It has a sci fi theme in space, with an interesting story divided into various acts, lots of distinct characters (including various playable ones), and of course, annoying puzzles that require a lot of experimentation. At least the areas aren’t huge, so the puzzles are somewhat self-contained. While episode I and II are smaller, III and IV expand in scope and length, and IV even has some light decisions that you must make. The graphics and music are a bit generic, but get the job done. Each episode has trading cards and achievements of their own, and they are cheap to get, with episode I even being free.
Of course, I can only recommend this saga if you´re a fan on the genre, because if you’re not you’ll quickly start to get frustrated. But if you do, you have a cheap and solid game here, especially for a small indie team.

61580699.review:
Although it's built using an engine intended for JRPGs the actual gameplay of the Space Pilgrim games is closer to that of the classic '90s point-and-click adventures: a variety of locations that can be visited, characters who can be spoken to, and items which can be picked up. By combining items and using them in the right situations you can move the plot forward. Most of the narrative is fairly linear, and is told through dialogue and the occasional cut-scene.

The plot of Episode I resembles a  classic "bottle-show" format for a space serial of some sort: on a freighter travelling between the stars something goes wrong and Captain Gail Pilgrim learns that the passengers she is transporting are not all exactly what they appear.

It's an entertaining narrative with some excellent characters, and the price really can't be beaten!

57397180.review:
This game came with a humble bundle I bought a couple years ago. It's a pretty short puzzle game in that point-and-click style of find objects, use them together, then use them on the environment to solve a puzzle, made in RPG Maker. The characters are fun, it's got a good heart, and it doesn't overstay it's welcome, plus it's free now, so I'd recommend it. It's about 2 to 2.5 hours long, and that's with interacting with every object in the game to see all the little funny text.

My only negative with this game (also a spoiler) is that it effectively has a plane hijacking by a religious fanatic in it (it's a spaceship with only 4 people and a cat on board though not a passenger jet, but it's literally the same thing given the game's universe). It didn't really bother me but it might bother other people. 55819297.review:
(Okay, IL PALLINO, you win!  I tried it and now I review it...curse you for getting me hooked...)

[h1]Is this episode of a space traveler really to be ranked alpha?[/h1]

Long ago, I heard about this game in an achievement hunting group...and as you know, [i]RPG Maker[/i] titles take time and commitment...some flooded with battles, the others dragging on with exposition...and map designs...oh my god are they often large with obligatory mazes.  And when I heard that this was a space game with a theme similar to [i]Star Trek[/i] (and how boring I find that...) I couldn't "nope" out of the room any faster...wasn't made any better knowing that I had a free copy of the "Academy" series in my library collecting dust.  Yet out of the blue, a user gifts me episode 2 and kept giving the series high marks.  I was tempted to refuse the gift, but his passion wouldn't let up and I couldn't bring myself to break his heart, knowing how it feels to be passionate about a series as a diehard fan...so I tried out episode 1 first...and quite frankly?  I was impressed.

[i]Space Pilgrim Episode I: Alpha Centauri[/i] is a short [i]RPG Maker[/i] title set in space following a girl named Gail Pilgrim who acts as an intergalactic taxi service, hauling people and goods from location to location.  However, we're not going to focus on that boring aspect because the game barely touches on it.  What it does touch on is the interactions of Gail and her passengers along with other people she meets to form a narrative between them.  While most [i]RPG Maker[/i] games utilize large environments to build their worlds, this particular title does the exact opposite to gain the same effect.  Smaller maps which actually makes me want to skip from map to map even faster, allowing me new scenery to look at from room to room.  This is a feature I greatly appreciated from the developer.

As far as the writing goes, I find it to be silly yet not overly random since the jokes are situational and arise only when necessary...with an occasional lesbian joke here and there.  The writing never pulls a joke that feels unwarranted or forced and each character's dialogue comes off naturally.  The format of writing feels good as does the interface.  My only real gripe is the "combine" system which makes things feel quite tedious, despite fitting into the "point-and-click" genre.

The story is approximately 2 hours long and I haven't found any bugs.  As for the franchise?  I guess now it's no real surprise as to why the franchise has prospered for four years (as of this review).  If you're looking for a clever little title for a few hours, I'd highly recommend giving [i]Space Pilgrim Episode I: Alpha Centauri[/i] a try.  It's free, short, has some achievements, and with some good writing.  I guess it's safe to say that I've become a bit of a fan now and am eager to see more of how this story unfolds.

9/10 Umm....Obligatory sci-fi space reference catchphrase here!

50321787.review:
So, this is more a review for the first four (aka the ones I have actually played), but without spoilers, so don't worry.

Space Pilgrim is a rather decent point & click adventure game, set (who'd have thought) in space. You mainly play as Gail Pilgrim, captain of her own space vessel, and right at the start, you're acting as a taxi for a small number of people. Of course, this doesn't go to plan, setting up the events of these first few episodes. The story as a whole is pretty good, it's very engaging and easy to follow, and lets you experience a variety of different locations.

In my opinion, the series' main advantage is its characters. They're very well-written and the main characters seem like real people, rather than two-dimensional, functional characters. Gail herself is a likeable and relatable protagonist, and the way she interacts with other characters is generally believable. The whole series isn't too serious, there's a fair amount of humour (but it doesn't overpower the game - there are some very serious moments, and the writing knows when to ease up on the laughs).

Each episode gives around 1-2 hours of gameplay (unless you are really good at these), so it's not a long game. The 'puzzles' aren't too obscure, but you'll often find you need to do X for character A, so that you can then do Y for character B and do Z for Character C, which was the main objective. Handily the journal helps you keep track of what you need to do. I've really enjoyed playing through this series, and I'll probably get the rest!

50191858.review: If you're in the mood for a nice, short, interesting Sci-Fi RPG maker experience, this is the way to go! The story is interesting, and the characters are written well. I have not played any other games in the series, and I'm looking forward to trying them!

50155389.review:
TLDR: This is a short game to a pretty amazing story. I have fallen in love with the characters and have replayed through the games (even speedrun them) and every time it's amazing to see where the saga began. Do yourself a favor and get the whole saga and play through it.

The game is a point and click (or move with arrows) to interact with the world around you. You play as Gail Pilgrim aboard her fathers ship (now hers) and you follow the story through her and her passengers. This game has elements of puzzles you have to figure out, this including; go here, combine this, get that etc. At first I thought this would become annoying but it's pleasantly fun, and it gets better throughout the series. The game focuses heavily on puzzles and story. So if you're looking for combat, not the game for you. However, if you want a well driven story, this is the game where you need to start. 

Cannot recommend enough. Get this game and the whole saga. #Sail The ship is sailing ;)

Totally charming. I 100%ed it in just under an hour, so it's a bite-sized game, but it was a very nice hour. There are 3 other episodes in the series that continue on directly from this one.

Great writing with some dry humor and nice snappy dialogue, and a fun little story that feels fresh. The dev really makes gold out of the simple RPGMaker engine with some creative uses of items and space. 

⋆ [b]Positives -[/b] Writing (quality of the dialogue). Story and setting. Characters: Great, unique characters with personality. Creativity and stretching the limitations of RPGMaker. Humor. Sound: I was surprised by how good the sound design/music was. It's simple and might have been done with stock stuff, but it works great. Graphics: It uses stock RPGMaker tiles, but I think it uses them well. The game looks crisp and cleanly put-together, so I didn't mind.

Ⓧ [b]Negatives -[/b] Inventory controls: A little finicky when using the mouse to play. OK with the keyboard, though, and it was just a minor annoyance since you spend very little time using the inventory.

40507857.review:
Overview:

Space Pilgrim Episode I: Alpha Centauri is a casual point-and-click RPG set in a sci-fi universe where Captain Gail Pilgrim makes her livelihood transporting cargo and passengers aboard her father's old starship.  In predictable fashion, something goes awry when the ship is in space, and the adventure begins.

Graphics and Sound:

What are you expecting for a game that you get "awarded" coupons for on Steam for crafting badges?  Alright, I won't cut any corners this time!  The graphics and sound are both comparable to the graphics and sound to games made in the fourth generation of consoles, which is good enough for me, since I find game graphics from that generation to be aesthetically pleasing, and this game's graphics are no exception.  There's nothing in particular that I like about the graphics, but there's nothing I would consider game-breaking about any of the graphics.

The ambient sounds in the background help set the mood, but they're nothing exciting.  Sadly, the sounds cannot be muted in-game, so if you want to listen to your kind of music, you'll need to mute your computer and play your kind of music from an outside source.

Positives:

This game represents a true value for the money.  Unlike all the other shovelware I've been given Steam coupons for after crafting badges that look like they're from the third generation of consoles, at least this game looks like it was from the fourth generation.  

I knew right away from the first bits of dialogue in the beginning that I was going to enjoy the characters and what all they would have to say.  Although there wasn't much room in the way of being able to express the characters, I found them to be incredibly interesting given the price of this game.  The dialogue was very enjoyable to read, and there was some unexpected humor, especially in the conversations involving the robots encountered.  

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1719058748

I also got a nice laugh when I tried to have Gail use a urinal. (Below image used with permission.)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=690982154&tscn=1519989267

If you're one of those people who buy games just for the sake of crafting badges, this game is for you!  There's only five cards, and the cards that are on the market as of the time of the writing of this review are quite cheap, so you can easily build yourself a shiny level five badge for your profile (along with earning yourself 500 XP), and top it off with an impressive foil badge for an additional 100 XP!

If you're the type of person who likes to say "I got every achievement to this game, I'm like, uber-1337"!  This game is also for you!  With seven achievements that are impossible not to achieve, you'll impress your friends in no time.  (Assuming, of course, your friends do not have this game!)

Negatives:

It's obvious that if there's something wrong with this game, it's the length of the game.  Seven achievements?  Yes, the length of this game is shorter than an ant's pecker.

While the dialogue is of high quality, I do find it lacking that there's never any choices to pick from when conversing with the other characters and robots.

Conclusion:

With zero difficulty, little adventure, and lack of choices for dialogue, this game plays more like a visual novel than an RPG.  But the reason anyone plays video games, is to have fun, and this game is good fun.  In fact, this game is far more fun than I ever would have expected for even it's regular sale price.  Coupons for this game aren't hard to come by, so get yourself a coupon if you can, and get ready to see where the adventures of Gail Pilgrim take you.  However short, it's probably for the better that the developer decided on making a bunch of individual short games instead of a bunch of mini-adventures stitched together for the sake of badge collectors with enough sense to know that a level five badge to a game with five cards to collect for a nickel counts for the same amount of XP as a level five badge featuring eight cards that all sell anywhere for a dime to a half-dollar each.  (And even more!)  If you own a software publishing company, you should buy out GrabTheGames, because their writers should be writing dialogue to games with far bigger distribution than what they're able to accomplish on their own.

Space Pilgrim Episode 1: Alpha Centauri is a point and click style adventure game. The story follows Captain Gail as she flies her passenger spaceship and embarks on a series of misadventures.

The game is short, taking a little over an hour to finish, and presumably leads into episode 2, which is a separate adventure. The plot is interesting, and the gameplay is mostly interacting with objects, for example finding a key to unlock a drawer, and combining two items into a useful tool to fix a broken machine. Speaking with other people is also a big part of progressing the story.

The game is well done, if a little short.

If you like this episode, it is recommended that you buy the other three. They are similar in style, continue the story, and Episodes 3 and 4 are each 3 times longer than this one.

I picked up this game awhile back, but I am only just now getting into it. I will be reviewing the games in order, starting with this one. 

Made using RPG Maker VS Ace, Space Pilgrim is a point and click adventure game that focuses on Captain Gail Pilgrim, who pilots a passenger ship charged with escorting a group of passengers from one destinatino to another. However one of her passengers is not what he seems, and he sets in motion a series of events that puts everyones lives at risk. The story is well written, with some humour and some serious moments in place. 

The graphics and sprites are large and aesthetically pleasing, with some decent music to be had. But the real meat here is the story, along with a short playtime and easy achievements. It definitely makes you want to play more, and play more I shall. I highly recommend you pick this up for yourself.

38956516.review:
I got a coupon for the  fourth game in the series, and I had played it for a short while before realizing that I wanted to play the whole set from the first episode. I'm not usually interested in the JRPG style, but this series has captivated me. An enjoyable spave adventure. My biggest warning for those who are unsure of whether they want it is that you will have to purchase at least 4 of the games to get a big chunk of story. Each game is relatively short, even shorter if you play quickly. It's not something I would expect to spend a huge amount of time on unless you're a bit slow like I am. 

If you are ready to get invested in a story, play this series. Although they are somewhat linear, the story is one that caught my attention quite well. They're on sale for super cheap right now. If I wasn't obsessed with buying things on sale, I would have bought the whole series the moment I started the 4th game. It's a simple RPGMaker series, so don't expect the mechanics to be any different from a basic run of the mill RPG. If it's your genre, this is a great game to add. If you get one, I recommend getting at least the first four so you can see the story through the 4th game.(altogether about 2USD at the moment)

If you haven't really enjoyed some of the RPGs you've played in the past but still want to find a series to bring you into the genre, this series is both cheap and entertaining as far as RPGs go. I have yet to finish them all, but this iteration has my thumbs up.

38046616.review: Easily the best RPG Maker game I've played since To the Moon and it isn't even an RPG. Space Pilgrim Episode I is a humorous science-fiction adventure game with witty dialog, interesting characters (especially the robots), a strong plot and puzzles that are just difficult enough to keep the player challenged for two to three hours. And, because it isn't an RPG, you don't have to deal with tedious, menu-driven monster battles. (Using the Inventory is occasionally tricky, though.) The price is so low that it should be affordable even to gamers on a tight budget, so if you enjoy adventure games and don't mind wandering through a landscape of familiar RPG Maker assets, it's well worth the cost. Recommended.

Sorry to say but one of the worst adventures i've ever played.
A little heads up: I only played the first episode and maybe about 10ish minutes into the 2nd one (that epislon thingy). I could not continue due to the lack of challenge and changing of scenes (i'll explain a few sentences later).
Sorry to the developer, i see your effort but either the story is compelling nor the puzzles in particular challenging and here is why:
everything changes alot. you fulfill one task and either the scene ends in an abrupt fade to black or suddenly changes complete objectives or plot. Its like i am in a bad action movie. There is nothing really to fail, just looking around for the one object that you can interact with. Most of the puzzles got solved by just looking around and exploring things.Its a very light adventure for the curios one.Sadly the plot or the characters do not make up for this.
SPOILERALERT:
For example in this first episode you board your ship with 3 passengers. Without getting too much into the characters (this is a priest, this is a soldier, this is a scientist) One of them gets immediatly insane and takes over the ship. The otherone gets almost killed and knocked out until the end of the game. And the third one almost breaks the fourth wall while knowing everything. And know the challenge: guess which characters has which behavior? You immediatly know what is going on.
Okay leaving this aside, what is the overall plot? There is a mad priest who wants to fly your ship into the ?sun? (refered as gate to heaven). But he gets killed without further explaining anything of his plot. This could have been a big potential for a great story but it got shut down too quickly. While gaining controll back over your ship the soldier gets knocked out also without any more context to this character. So you are going to look for help and find a mining space station where people seem to act weird. But why? Never explained. Intead your rummage around their space station, treating everyone like shit and wonder why they are mad at you (duh). When they come after you, you just kill them? or at least trapping them forever alone in space, left to die, unconscious.
And in the end: Yeah we're all alive and escaped. From what? From the people that you seeked for help, which they provided, and killed? Woohoo...Next episode! And here only one character made it over (maybe the soldier comes back for a visit in the future? I dont know what happened to him) - the rest is a fresh start in the same setting.
The only thing I know about the main antagonist at this point that she has her ship handed over by her father to contitnue his business and I guess she likes cats (cause there is one on her ship) but is willing to sacrifice it in a wimp of an eye?).
There could be so much more made out of the story with the mad priest or the wounded soldier but instead you hire the scientist because you got along so well? Its not like a 2nd crew member was needed before...
I cannot see an overall story and the first episode just made me not want to explore it.
And, as I said, the puzzles made not up for that. The 2nd episode begins with the act "Play stewardess" - after all this and the computer telling me to look around my passengers (probably to introduce the new chars) I did not want to continue because I knew, I'd be running around and asking every person to get to a new scene where probably something dramatic happen. And every other puzzle was the same. You look for objects to interact, make a connection from that object to a person and maybe sometimes add an item to find in the bathroom or so (also only actions become available after you interacted with another person or object what is very frustrating to do everything in the right order or just speak to that person for no reason again to do the thing you wanted to do).
And unfortunatley exploring solves the problems ahead, you dont know about. For example there was a butterfly on the space station. One of the few animated ojects on your way, so I immediatly want to explore it. When you try to catch it, it went through a vent, you go back one room and there is the butterfly. Interact again, it flew to the next room. And when you enter the room suddenly a little scene plays with one of the station members trying to catch it and losing his key while catching. Now I got keys from a character which I dont know what to do with and a char who I never got the chance to speak first. That was a little bit odd to say the least.
And prying open a chest full of explosives with a metal stick that appeared while a big robot shot at you to actually kill the robot was also not very challening.

Overall:
Massive potential waste, in my eyes. Maybe there builds up a bigger plot in the 2nd or 3rd episode but the 1st one scared me off with all the running arounds and fulfilling a task list to get to the next task list.

34299227.review:
Having this gifted to me from a friend who got the humble bundle I decided to try it out. Of course this is coming off of just this game not the series as a whole.

I am fully aware that the first game one makes on RPG Maker isn't really the best one or the one where the creator puts most of their dedication to perfect. This could have been a game that was probably used to flesh out the skills the creator needed for the rest of the series. If that was the case then I don't see why the game wasn't just one giant game rather than 4 different episodes. This would have allowed for seeing what lacked in certain parts and add a bit of more repolishing to it. The reason I bring this up is cause while the gameplay wasn't bad, as someone who uses RPG Maker to design his own games, I felt it lacking. 

This first episode suffers something that a game like this should not have, it is too short for it's own good. There isn't much time to get to know the characters as the game instantly sets you up into a dire situation you have to get out of. There is no time to learn the characters and grow attached to them which is what a first episode is usually meant for. This in my own opinion is heavily detremental to a game as a whole. 

Another thing that felt off to me is that the characters didn't have different face portraits for different pieces of diolouge. While not necessarily a major issue it does somewhat take away the experience of emmersing your player into the world by making your characters feel a bit more alive. It doesn't make sense for someone who is worried about your character to be smirking or for a character to be smiling while things are going sour. A few other facial expressions for the characters other than the standard ones would have been a way to resolve this. A few minutes off your time to make various portaits of the same character with different expressions doesn't take much time especially if you are using VX Ace's character creator.

The story itself felt like it went barely anywhere. It kinda felt like everything that happened in this game just happened to have it happen. Again going back to the fact that it seemed to be too short for it's own good. None of the scenarios you go through felt very fleshed out in this episode.

I do not know if these issues are fixed in the future episodes for I have yet to try them. However, this episode was not a very good start. It was ok but it wasn't up to my expictations of what the start of a series should be like. I cannot recommend this episode in particular. I'll eventually see what the others have to offer but if anything I can almost garuntee you can skip this episode and you will not have much of an issue understanding the rest of the game.

34207122.review:
I bought this as part of the Humble micro Bundle, it’s not something I would normally choose and it’s the first RPG Maker game I have played. It’s a 2.5D, pixel art, point and click adventure set in space and would normally cost £0.90 on Steam. I completed in the game in just under 2 hours with 7/7 achievements.

Things didn’t get off to a good start; episode one launched in teeny tiny windowed mode with no options available on the start menu or in game to change this. I used Alt + Return to get the game to full screen but it was stuck in 800 x 600 resolution. About 20 minutes into the game I pressed F12 in a vain attempt to take a screen shot and received the message “script ‘mouse support’ line 131: RGSSerror occurred. Dispose sprite” and the game closed without saving. There are actually no auto-save points, this needs to be done manually.

The story and characters (in episode one at least) are largely as two dimensional as the visuals, and the dialogue can be a bit stale. Everything felt a bit generic and the plot was a tad on the simple side, with events/puzzles playing out a bit too conveniently. There was nothing challenging about this episode and it offered nothing new. The best part was actually a side plot involving two robots in Act 3. This proved far more emotive than anything happening in the main story arch and the robots themselves were well written characters given their screen time.

The ending was somewhat anti-climactic. I won’t spoil anything but will suffice to say it was all too neat. There was no cliff-hanger or suspense to motivate me to play the next episode, everything wraps up in a way a bit too close to ‘happily ever after’ and left me feeling unsatisfied.

There are some positives, once you get past the above foibles. It’s nicely made for what is, and it was a fairly relaxing experience. If you particularly like this sort of game it is most likely worth the low price but it’s not for everyone and I probably wouldn’t recommend it.



If you enjoyed this and would like to see my game reviews (and a bunch of other ramblings) in their natural habitat please visit my [url=www.rachaelbreartonwrites.com]blog[/url]

30861841.review:
Space Pilgrim Episode 1 is a short point and click adventure game set in space. An obvious RPGMaker game, with a sci-fi setting and a straightforward plot.

The story begins on Union Space Station, orbiting the planet Brahman and 6.6 light years away from Earth. Our plucky young protagonist, Gail Pilgrim, is tasked with transporting 3 passengers on her ship Quicksilver to planet Adroa in Alpha Centauri - a simple job which soon goes sideways when a stowaway is revealed to taken over piloting the  ship to a new destination. Now Gail must deal with the threat on her ship and whatever is at the new location her ship has been diverted to.

As it is a point and click game, the game works by clicking on items in the game or your inventory and then selecting what you want to do with, and as expected you will need to combine items to advance past some obstacles. The puzzles are easy and not really much of a challenge, giving the impression of a prologue episode. The additional of a journal to keep track of the missions is handy, I found it easy to get lost in exploring the world and forget which order steps needed to be taken in.
There are some nice little touches which give some life to the game. When speaking with people you can get a little more information about the setting, being able to see a message from your father and the option of using the restroom is an interesting addition. The dialogue can feel a little flat in some places, but each character has their own mannerisms and distinct personality, plus there are a couple of tasteful references to sex.

Art wise, the characters all have a distinctive look and each sprite is each to recognise in game. The background is suitably drab in parts and vibrant in others, depending on which location Gail is in. It adds to the impression of a busy bar or small spaceship, the details in the overview of the Quicksilver is well done and makes it stand out against the inky blackness of space.
For the music, a couple of licenses have been obtains to play some already existing music, which has been carefully selected to fit in to the sci-fi setting and adds a little bit of atmosphere.

It is a short game, easy to complete in about an hour and a bit generic, though it could be forgiven as this is the opening episode introducing us to our protagonist. I am happy to give this a thumbs up as the game knows what it is and focuses on it, I am hopeful the later episodes are longer and a bit more complex.

30172422.review:
Well, after having had so many bad experiences with RPG Maker games, I am actually pleased to see one which is actually good. Maybe because it's nothing like the other RPG Maker games and tries to be original, which definitely came as a pleasant surprise.

To tell you the truth, I got tired of all the same stories and settings present in RPG Maker games. It's always high fantasy, always some legendary warrior on a quest to slay goblins, wolves and slimes. This game her,e however, takes place in a Sci-Fi setting with no fighting. Instead it tells a story by making you solve simple puzzles in a way a point and click game normally would.
I welcomed the change because I got tired of all the battles in which you would spam "attack" all the time anyway. There are no battles here, just a story to experience. And since RPG Maker games are always quite simplistic, that's the best use for them anyway. Coming up with good and fun gameplay mechanics for this kind of engine is hard, even more so getting the balance of combat right. Many RPG Maker games struggle because of this and fail because they have to do all that and create a immersive story on top of it.

So it makes sense that this game ditches battles and balancing altogether in favor of creating a fun story and compelling characters instead.

And it works.

The story, albeit short, is genuinely interesting enough to get you absorbed into the world, if you are willing to allow it. The characters have their unique traits and feel alive. There are a lot of things you can examine as the MC to get many interesting lines from both the MC and her companions, even very humorous ones at times. The game also looks rather good for a RPG maker game. Sprites fit the atmosphere and setting and every character has their own portrait, even irrelevant ones.

All in all, I can say that this is an RPG maker game that had some serious effort put into it and you can tell by playing it. This isn't the usual trash that gets put together in a hurry to put it on steam and make some cash. And even though it is quite short and cut into four parts, I would still wholeheartedly recommend this series for being one of the better games the RPG maker niche has to offer.

26290390.review:
I will start with outlining a couple of characteristics first - this game consists of:

- RPG-style graphics with adventure point-&-click game mechanics (i.e. inventory, items, journal for game progression, clicking, interacting with environment, saving option)

- 3 acts

- 2 playable characters

- a handful of additional characters (some of these end up as allies, whereas others as antagonists)

- a duo of funny robots

- some funny lines

Now on to the game specifics:

The art style is cute and very much like JRPGs, though the game plays more like an adventure point-&-click.

It is simplistic & basic but fun & very straightforward (not difficult to figure what to do next).

Great for those times when you want to relax, have some fun and keep yourself busy.

There's an inventory, that contains whatever item that can be picked up in your environment and are expected to use for some kind of purpose.

Like any good adventure game, there's also a journal to keep track of the dialogues and objectives (thank god!). If it wasn't for this, I would've forgotten what I needed to do next.

As for game progression; at times you're prompted to combining items so as to create a more fitting object in order to proceed further.

The characters reveal in a very straightforward manner what their intentions are and what they need to execute their plans. It's a no-brainer really.

It looks fairly easy on the eye and there's no brain-busting puzzles (phew!).

I absolutely loved the portrets. They looked close enough to the character sprites.

I find cohesion and consistency very important (in any type of game).

This game definitely looks and feels cohesive & consistent (from character design, to environmental design to story progression).

The story is well written as well and it made sense.

It was definitely worth the investment (not that this game costs an arm and a leg - far from it).

I got it on sale (including 4 Space Pilgrim chapters) + an additional game by the same developer (for the curious people reading this, I'm referring to 'Crown Champion Legends of the Arena') - which cost me less than 5 bucks.

The developers are definitely not afraid of trying things and dabbling into different genres. I really like that and I appreciate it (and they use RPGmaker every single time).

I'm amazed at what they've squeezed out of this piece of software (which enables developers to focus on the artsy aspect without needing to break their heads too much in regard to any intricate technical stuff).

They really do seem like they care about what people have to say and try to implement feedback and improve their material.

There's definitely great potential here and if they continue like this, I do believe they could create something beautiful & rich (one step at a time!).

I absolutely love investing in people who care this much and are capable of delivering decent quality products, time after time.

It's very heartwarming and beautiful to see how they're progressing with every title that is released and I am so proud of them, because they serve as a great example of what it means to start small, and grow bigger.

I'm curious to see more! I give credit where credit is due and they deserve every bit of it.

PS I wouldn't mind investing in some of the artwork :).

This game, despite its basic graphics, was a happy find! More of an interactive story than a point and click adventure, the storyline is engaging, witty, and satisfying. I completed the game in under 90 minutes (with all achievements), so it is not a long game, but you can pick up the bundle of all 5 episodes for a very reasonable price.

I'm writing this review before I play the other episodes so I can give an unbiased review to just this episode.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- Great storyline
- Interesting characters
- Straight forward game play
- No frustrating puzzles/random inventory combining
- Can be played as stand-alone story (do not need other episodes) if you want to try it out.
- Steam trading cards and realistic achievements (if you like that)

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Very small windowed gameplay
- Inventory menu not brilliant - can be frustrating trying to combine objects on the few occasions you need to
- Pixel graphics - can't say I'm a fan, lived through that in the 80s!
- Not much in way of soundtrack. Can turn on intercom music and a few effects.
- Short, sorry to see it end.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
If you're happy with a point and click story, and like to check out every object in a classic adventure gamer obsession, then you will really like this game!
8.5/10

A fun little sci-fi adventure game. I liked it for its well-developed setting and interesting characters.

A note about genres: Although this is an RPGMaker title, there's no combat in the game; instead it's about talking to people, and using items in the environment to solve problems. So it's not really an "RPG", but more in the vein of a point-and-click adventure game.

I recommend this game if you like point-and-click adventures, and you care more about writing than graphics. The graphics are standard RPGMaker stuff, workable but not outstanding. The game by itself is fairly short (I finished it in an hour), but it's only the first, and shortest, chapter in a four-part series where each game directly continues the storyline from the last one. Taken altogether, the whole series takes around 10 hours to play, and costs about four dollars, which is not a bad deal.

This was an enjoyable retro adventure game.

The story was interesting enough to keep me playing and the puzzles were not so obtuse as to have me wandering all over ship and station looking for answers.

It's made with RPGMaker, but that does not imply RPG elements.  It's a straight up adventure game.  If I'd used the mouse instead of the keyboard, it would have been a point-and-click.

One con is that there are zero configurable options and the game starts in a *small* window.  Fortunately, you can use ALT-Enter to go fullscreen.  It still doesn't scale all the way (probably fixed multiples) and it certainly isn't widescreen, but it still looks nice.

One tip: Do examine everything.  You'll find easily identifiable objects laying about rooms, but there are also many usable objects on walls that you will need.

Also, for something with such a low level of complexity, I really wish it was cross platform.  I'd much rather be playing in Linux instead of have to reboot into Windows.  I don't know much about RPGMaker, but I had assumed it would help with multiple platforms the way Unity does.

Looking forward to playing the other episodes.

24138397.review:
My playtime: 1:08:06 (before last cutscene, based on internal clock)

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Space Pilgrim Episode I: Alpha Centauri is an adventure game about a hijacked spaceship. You'll spend most of your time interacting with objects to find usable items and reading through the story.

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music really fits with the environment, outer space. The SFXs are also used very well.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The sprite selection is very beautiful and so is the mapping. The only complaint i have is the mining background which looks quite odd with the building. The thing that i like the most is when the screen shows the current position and displays information.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is short and to the point. However, i didn't find it boring. In fact, i'm enjoying it. Although it's written as Episode 1, the ending satisfy me and doesn't leave any cliffhangers.

[h1]The game[/h1]
You'll interact with objects or person in order to finish the objectives. The objectives are listed in the menu, under Journal menu. You can combine items which you have find or use them. However, i find that the use item menu to be quite confusing, because you usually interact with a particular object to use the item. It took me a while to find out that i have to use the item from the menu twice: when i have to blow up the machine and when i have to use the gloves.

Pros:
- Short and to the point story

Cons:
- Using item through menu might be quite confusing

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This is a short RPG Maker adventure game about hijacked spaceship.

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you love to buy RPG Maker game, this one is a must. However, if you are the type who think twice before buying RPG Maker game, because of its length, you might want to skip it or buy it when it's on sale.[/i]

23695685.review:
Honestly, I can't believe how much I found myself enjoying this game.

I can't say my expectations were particularly high. I purchased it in a "10 games for a dollar" type of bundle, and expected more of the usual tripe that comes from both bundles and RPG Maker.

What I like about RPG Maker, in theory, is that it allows enterprising story-tellers and novelists to weave a story without the trammel of having to have coding skills, technical prowess, or much knowledge about anything pertinent to the computer sciences. Unfortunately, the same features which give RPG Maker these qualities also attract the lazy, the unimaginative, and the pretentious, emboldened by the success of games such as To the Moon, which, with small development teams, have risen to sales prominence.

Thankfully, this one is entirely the former. I won't spoil too much; it's a short game, and I love it when people just let the action unfold. I will say, while there are some issues with the puzzles (Or, maybe it's just me? I can never tell), where some of the objects of interest are /very/ difficult to find/realize owing to how small their sprites are, and how well some of them blend into the background they're against, the characters all have individual personalities (I keep finding games in this genre where everyone was written with kind of the same voice, even if they say different things), the scriptwriting is excellent, the plot is written well enough to where I was /genuinely/ surprised by one or two things, and, by the end, I actually cared about what happened to everyone. 

I've been recommending this to my friends, and I recommend it to you. It's often on sale for around 50 cents; if you're patient, I would wait until then. Otherwise, I'd say it's worth $1.99 for the story, but, it's a little short to justify the price. (1-2 hours)

In short, I do recommend this game (RPG = point and click adventure, not a role playing one) and you can/should buy it and all its following episodes (I to IV combined) if:
- you don't care much about graphics in a game and therefor if
- you're actually willing to let your own fantasy create a far more beautiful universe than that one depicted on your screen. ;-)

It's definitely not the graphic - RPG Maker, no more, no less - that got me hooked but the rather interesting adventure arc evolving around captain Gail Pilgrim and her co-pilot Sabina White during a time of galactic struggle.

From the first episode about a simple human space transport to the final one concluding the adventure (so far) there are some interesting places, people, and universal theories introduced to the player which makes the story arc expanding around 10+ hours in total (ep. I to IV).

Of course, the background story won't go as far as in Mass Effect, and the riddles and tasks to solve are mostly on the easy to medium side; however, for that amount of money you should definitely give the game a try.

Think of it as a SciFi novel that you buy in a book store for reading during the holidays, it's interesting enough to make the time go by faster and reread it after a couple of years.

Thanks again to the devs, I actually liked it and would like to see some kind of Space Pilgrim ep. V.

21794944.review: What a lovely little game. I consume a lot of sci-fi, and this one pleasantly surprised me. Often indie games like this depend heavily (and fail epicly) on the writing, but this has eminently plausible dialog and a positive feel to it. I enjoyed the dialog so much it was a shame that there was no option to engage in dialog trees. Perhaps this is an RPG Maker limitation? I've only played one other RPG Maker game (To The Moon), so i was prepared to face pointless fetch quests, but Space Pilgrim manages to spice it up a bit by making the fetch quests meaningful and adding some simple inventory puzzles. For the price, this is one of the neatest sci-fi adventures i've played recently.

21790106.review:
A leitmotiv among Space Pilgrim Ep. 1's numerous positive reviews are that "it is a good game for the price".

The price being [i]nintey cents[/i], this might in fact not be a very good game at all.

There is little point in being overly harsh about something that wasn't offensive in any way (except for the typo on Dvořák in the credits). [i]Space Pilgrim[/i] is a space-themed point-and-click adventure made in RPG Maker that will last you less than two hours. The game is linear and offers no challenge at all (it is impossible to die/fail), so don't expect any replay value. The visual and audio design, albeit not horrid, is exceptionally average and uses a lot of existing assets (which, fairly enough, are properly mentioned in the credits).

So what is left to enjoy? The story and the writing quality. Once again, nothing offensively atrocious there; it is just... painfully average. The story has as little depth as you'd expect from such a short adventure. The dialogue has its moments, with a few chuckles coming from the clash between the scientist's cynical demeanor and Captain Pilgrim's simple-minded antics... but that's pretty much it. Nothing really memorable stands out. Surely there was room for more character development and slightly deeper exchanges, even within the context of a two-hour adventure.

I will most certainly concede that [i]Space Pilgrim[/i] is fair for its price; but I wouldn't go so far as to recommend playing it, unless you're an absolute sucker for short sci-fi stories and you feel that actual books have too many complicated words.

21713094.review:
Refreshing little game which I bought on sale on a whim. I kinda liked it. The game tells a story of Gail Pilgrim and a few of her associates. Instead of being a hard-boiled space marine veteran, she's just a girl who's trying to make a living by transporting passengers and cargo around the galaxy on a spaceship, which she inherited from her father. She also has an uncanny ability of getting herself and her cat, Zubar, into hazardous situations.

The writing is good enough to last through the games, and the story works surprisingly well. Don't expect anything jaw-dropping, though: the game is basically a point-and-click adventure game where you run around while solving some very simple puzzles. The game mechanics remind me a bit of the old Pokemon-games on Gameboy Color. Got a warm and fuzzy feeling playing through these games. Controller works, but there's one quirk which I dislike - sometimes when skipping conversations with the action button, it's quite easy to start it over and over again.

Can recommend overall, since the price is pretty much that of a lollipop.

A cute and short point & click adventure game. Kind of reminded me of the old Sierra quests from the 1990s, except it took me just a little over an hour to beat. 20953172.review:
Gail Pilgrim is a ship pilot, transporting passengers in space. This time, she has three persons: a retired colonel, a clever scientist and a crazy Russian priest that is reciting passages from the Bible. However, nearing the end of the journey, someone took the commands of the ship... How will Gail regain the control and save her passengers? And why people at Innes Station where she's docking because of an emergency are behaving weirdly too?

This little adventure game was made with RPG Maker, true, so, the style and the HUD is known. But the story is well-written: you go from twist to twist, you're playing two characters actually (Gail then someone else in act III) and you have some good humor in it (Gail is maybe a good girl but she's not really confident in herself).

The gameplay is easy: you search for items, you discuss with people and nope, you don't have any hidden object scenes - because usually that kind of beginning for the sentence is often found in my review about HOG. Anyway, you can combine items in your inventory when needed. Keep in mind that sometimes, you need to go to the inventory and examine more closely items in order to advance in the game - I was kinda stuck twice because I didn't think about this action.

The soundtrack is also a good one. I loved the fact that you can activate the intercom to play music and to enable finally something to listen instead of the void.

Seriously, for the price, you have a little good moment to enjoy. True, it's short - you can complete the game in 1 hour. However, I'm looking forward to the other episodes (I've the second one in my library and at the time of the writing, the third one is in my wishlist). Go ahead!

20555466.review:
Space Pilgrim is a JRPG-style adventure game that can be created with RPG Maker VX without being a slave to the RPG convention. Its 8-bit look can be extremely annoying, and the lack of obvious "action" parts (and thus, the need to roam the cursor all over the place to seek the action spots) is a bit of PITA. The difficulty of combining parts to create a combo part to solve a particular puzzle is somewhat PITA as well. Basically, it's not clear how you can interact with certain parts. 

While it breaks no ground, and this is nowhere near a commercial quality release, with a bit more polish (16-bit sprites, better overall resolution, better character portrait that matches trading cards instead of the 8-bit sprite-look, better interface)  this can be a proper shareware style title with a free or deeply discounted first episode and paid multiple episodes or subscription. 

The story is decent, and while not a long game, for one episode is is sufficiently long. The puzzles are obvious enough so must of my gripes are fighting the interface. 

All in all, if you are yearning for some old-style point-and-click adventure, this may scratch the itch.

An extremely good game all round. Not without its flaws, but no game ever is ;)

THE GOOD
Nice concept
A couple of good story twists
Some humor
Bug free
You can look at and interact with pretty much everything

THE BAD
No fullscreen mode. There's a commercial game script available for RPG Maker which does this; I hope the developer looks into it for subsequent games
Limited crew interaction. Despite one character inviting you to talk to his crew, you can only really interact with and question one of them

AND THE JUST PLAIN MISC
This game is very short; I completed it in just under an hour. For some, that may not be enough, but for the price, it's a very fair deal. Some people may take longer.
The inventory system is rather clumsy (understandable since RPG Maker wasn't designed to make adventure games) but once you get used to it, it's not too bad

So for the price, I definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a short break!

20274408.review:
A nice little point-and-click adventure, or the first episode of it anyway. While it isn't anything groundbreaking either in story, writing or character design, it isn't bad at any of those either.

1. Writing is decent to good, with some endearing humour and enough detail to line out the characters. Hopefully subsequent episodes will build on that and build good, well-defined and multi-dimensional characters on this foundation.

2. The story is good, some tiny twists and turns... I like that the background music forshadows the events to unfold. Subtle, but good.

3. Characters have a good foundation, but no depth so far. That is to be expected from such a very short game.

4. The sound design is a tad bit lacking in quantity, but what is there fits the game very well.

5. Mechanically the game is very well done, for the most part. This, fortunately, isn't one of those pixel-hunting adventures - all interactables are pretty easy to find and interact with. The mouse controls seem to be a bit weird, don't really know why, but they feel slightly choppy and imprecise. Also, the game starts in windowed mode for whatever reason. Due to the nature of the game, this are just tiny annoyances, but would be nice to see them disappear in future episodes/complete release.

6. The "puzzle" part of the game is shallow, but enjoyable. Most things are really easy to figure out, so far nothing to really strech your braincells. Simple but effective... it might be boring for veterans of this genre, but for relative newcommers like me, it was good enough.

All in all, a good game, well-worth the price. I sure hope the follow-up episodes will be this good, or better as well.

It was a fine game - it's price (0.99€, recently got a ~50% discount) is fair compared to it's about 1.5 hours of content.  (Thanks for the gift, ValkyrieMoon!)
Truth to be told, I wanted to talk about the game's story first, but an important thing for future buyers:  THIS IS NOT AN RPG. Each and every items strictly has it's usage, the story is straightforward, there is no choicemaking. This game is a point and click - pretty good at it, but I wanted to make this clear - no fighting in the game, or quests, or whatsoever.

I think the developer(s?) liked Firefly, at least I felt some resemblances to the series both in some minor elements, and the overall atmosphere of the game  - it has a serious, normal story, but quote often something funny or unexpected pops up - " my longest serving companion" is a plant, there's the lampiest lamp of the room, something silly. Like the captain gets bored during flights and start being a little crazy.
The story felt like a random episode of a sci-fi show - short, somewhat cliché, but likeable, while I wasn't hyped about what will happen next, I played through the game without getting bored at all, that's a good sign. I perticularly loved the robots in the third chapter - they mixed up the themes of Asimov's robotics with some feeling, existential of robots and humans - it was really intresting, that was the best written part of the game in my opinion.
About language and music... others mentioned typos, I don't recall any. Others mentioned good music, while usually I felt that the game's music was really underwhelming, usually I haven't even noticed it.  Or maybe the sounds effects were louder than the music and I turned down the volume... I think that this doesn't matter that much. The game is a good way to pass an hour if you want nothing more than a dose of sci-fi episode of a series you like - I'll keep an eye on the next episodes, hope they'll fare well.

20102090.review:
I want to say first that the developer shows some promise. I don't want that to get lost when I don't recommend the game.

The premise was interesting and on sale for $0.50, how could I not check it out? Based on how things start, I was ready for a good little horror game. It'd be like Alien; stuck on a ship with an unknown threat. The developer is great at setting up atmosphere. The music was perfect and the characters set a good tone. Thumbs up on having me turn down the lights. Unfortunately, there was no real payoff and it ended very anticlimactically. The gameplay is very simple as you just do one task after the other. It's just a matter of finding the right thing to interact with. The characters are not that interesting. One is crazy, one is nice, and the other one is "Jerk Spock". Two of them do have a little philosophical argument that was interesting, but it never goes anywhere, unfortunately. 

The second act is very similar in that you can tell something strange is going on and you're waiting for the other shoe to drop. Again, the ultimate "reveal" isn't very interesting. The third act actually has two interesting characters, but again it's their interaction with each other that is the best part, so you really have nothing to do with that and are just an observer. 

Ultimately, there isn't enough here to be worth your time or money, but the developer does show some talent that can be built on for future projects.

Edit: Also, my play time is not reflective of game length. I had it running in the background while I did other things. It's very short.

[u][h1]Original Review Re-edited in 2019:[/h1][/u]
[u][b]What is Space Pilgrim Episode 1: Alpha Centurai?[/b][/u]
Space Pilgrim Episode One: Alpha Centauri is a decently made, low price low budge RPG Maker title of very good quality.
It is an RPG in the form of story telling with linear game play; you play a role as a Captain of a space ship. Expect to play this role specifically.

[u][b]Episodes: "Is this not a whole game?"[/b][/u]
It is Episode 1 of four episodes of the now larger Space Pilgrim series. 
This "season" of four episodes is followed by several other titles including prequels/sequels/back stories. 

The Space Pilgrim universe has evolved rapidly and well in the past four years.
Episode 1 consists of three acts, which equaled about 1.5 hours play time, while each episode following is progressively longer and content/quality filled as the developers skills improved.

[u][b]Looks/Navigation:[/b][/u]
The environments have an appealing look to them.
The ship is laid out fairly logically. The mapping of the rooms is good. 
It looks and feels like a quirky spaceship.
There is not much back and forth walking; you will become confused if you skip the reading or have a derpy moment or two but that is it. Very straight forward and relaxing.
You can tell they tried to make the game engaging and not repetitive, but sometimes it is or at the worst it has little replay value. 
By episode 2 on wards they have vastly improved many of these very minor issues, which are matter of taste any way.

There is complete mouse support, which is great because there are a lot of things to interact with and moving about is very relaxing with a mouse click. The only pathing issue I have ever had was the cat walking in front of me, which is so minor where you just walk around.

[u][b]Gameplay:[/b][/u]
The inventory works well. 
There were initial issues navigating it and fusing items. This is mainly because the developer chose to tell the player how the inventory works at the very start of the game so by the time you get to doing so you have long forgotten that brief note. 
You can tell they tried really hard not to impact the story with annoying how-to pop ups
There is a journal, which I found useful as a reference point, (*No more lag in journal tab switching.)

[u][b]Soundtrack/Atmosphere:[/b][/u]
The music is immersive with a nice Mass Effect type feeling, although slightly more retro sounding.
The game has a very appealing corny space theme in general. 
I strongly feel like I am playing an episode of Firefly here.

[u][b]Story:[/b][/u]
The writing is quite solid if corny and definitely humorous.
It is a typical science fiction universe.
The future episodes have even better writing and humor.
The writing quality ties in with characters and character interaction; the characters are pretty cliched, but not in a bad way. 
You can have several conversations for minor character development. 
There are quite a few amusing one liners and the situations the characters get themselves into or discuss just make you chuckle.

I enjoyed the pacing of the story. A few times I found myself interested enough to be guessing what happens next, which means I was engaged, contrary to my first assumptions about an RPG Maker style episodic game, (which usually makes many people iffy to want to invest in.)

[u][b]Conclusion:[/b][/u]
All in all, I enjoyed my experience playing this first episode and was grinning as the game transitioned to the credits. 
There are [b]no[/b] glitches or issues running this game.
If I were to describe the story I would compare it to watching an episode of Firefly; 
the episode has its introduction, then problems arise, then the characters aim is to fix those problems or mysteries which then interestingly unfolds in front of your eyes. 
By the end of the episode things are wrapped up, leaving you wondering what mysteries and problems will happen next episode...

[u][i]Thanks for a decently designed, written and enjoyable sci-fi game Pilgrim Adventures!
I am so glad to see you still active with game development in 2019.
I feel you have talent in this industry and in delivering fun to players.[/i][/u]

19840098.review:
As Gail Pilgrim you embark on yet another voyage ferrying passengers through space: this time though what started as a milk run will soon become an unexpected and dangerous adventure.
The first episode of a planned tetralogy offers a decent story and simple puzzles in a short yet quite enjoyable adventure.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-decent story is, most of the time, quite cheerful but also sports some more serious twists

-there's a good amount of humor to be found and while most of it is pretty silly it's still decent enough to elicit a few chuckles

-while part of a series and finishing with a "to be continued" this chapter has a self-contained story with a proper ending

-the soundtrack is pretty nice and gives a good sci-fi vibe

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]

-being part of a series means we won't have the full 10 hours story arc until all the chapters are released

-puzzles are quite easy, don't expect your brain to be challenged

[b]CONS:[/b]

-fully linear, short at about 1 hour to complete

-while decent the story won't win any awards for originality so far, the characters are effective in their roles but come out as pretty cliched

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=581092885

Space Pilgrim Episode One: Alpha Centauri was pretty good considering its price and low budget, while the story and characters aren't that original they're still good enough to keep the narrative going: the often present humor also adds a certain charm to the game and results in a few funny scenes.

The resulting game is quite basic in its plot and gameplay but still enjoyable if you're ok with this lighter fare: within its limitations it still does basically everything right with a tale featuring a few twists and puzzles requiring you to sometimes combine items together. 

As things stands and considering the small price Space Pilgrim Episode One earns a recommendation from me as it is a decent way to spend one hour and its self-contained nature means you don't have to wait for the next chapters to enjoy this now.

19837591.review:
About an hour of play time in total. Exactly what it said on the tin. A narrative game built on an RPG engine with no combat, no branching, and simple puzzles.

I'm still recommending it. Accepting that it's short and linear, the writing was uncommonly decent. I've played a lot of big-budget games with incomprehensible stories and inane dialogue. Even though this was a very straightforward science fiction story, it was well done in comparison.

19832323.review: From what I have played so far, I have already considered removing the rest of my steam games and just playing this for the rest of my life. The story is fresh, engaging and the game's universe seems very interesting as well.
